name: Cybersecurity Fundamentals
description: This KU covers the current cybersecurity threat landscape, including the various motivations, objectives, and threats. This knowledge reinforces adversarial thinking and the need for cybersecurity. Students must also be able to describe cybersecurity goals, how risk management informs the approach to cybersecurity, and the principles and best practices of cybersecurity.
outcomes: Define the fundamental principles of cybersecurity.
Describe the goals of cybersecurity.
Describe the potential objectives of cyber attackers and their motivations.
Describe various types of cyber attacks.
Describe various common vulnerability types and evaluate their severity.
Describe different types of malware.
Describe common mechanisms used to protect against cyber attacks.
Given a specific scenario, identify potential protection mechanisms and design principles.
Describe the components of access control and how they are implemented.
Discuss current events in cybersecurity.
topics: Cybersecurity/McCumber Cube (Confidentiality, Integrity, and Availability (CIA) Triad, Information States, Security Controls)
Authentication, authorization, and accounting (AAA) and access control

name: IT Systems Components
description: This KU covers a basic understanding of the components of an information technology system and their roles in system operation. It provides a high-level introduction or familiarization with the topics rather than a deep dive into specifics.
outcomes: Describe the various hardware components of modern computing environments and their individual functions.
Characterize the networks that interconnect computing components.
Describe the various IT activities and roles involved in managing computing systems.
Understand system and software architectures.
Describe how software is managed within an organization.
Understand basic security issues in modern computing environments.
topics: Endpoint protection (workstations, personal computers, servers, appliances, mobile devices, peripherals)
Storage Devices (external storage drives, filesystems, shared file servers, databases)
System Architectures (enterprise, cloud, SaaS/PaaS/IaaS, etc.) and enabling technologies (containers, virtualization)
Managed Services Alternative environments (SCADA, real-time systems, critical infrastructures)
System and application software updates, patching
Networks (Internet, LANs/WANs, wireless, Internet of Things)
Cyber-physical systems (SCADA, real-time systems, critical infrastructure)
Network security components (firewalls, VPNs, monitors, intrusion detection systems)

name: Basic Scripting and Programming Fundamentals
description: This KU covers foundational skills in scripting and programming, focusing on enabling students to write simple scripts to automate tasks and perform basic programming operations.
outcomes: Write simple scripts to automate system administration tasks.
Write programs in a high-level language using basic programming constructs and concepts.
Implement basic security practices in scripting, including bounds checking and input validation.
Demonstrate conceptual understanding and practical use of regular expressions.
Demonstrate the use of basic data structures and algorithms.
topics: Control structures (conditional execution, selection, loops, branching)
Program safety (bounds checking, input/parameter validation, type checking)
Scripting platforms in various operating systems

name: Mathematics for AI
description: This KU covers the fundamental mathematics necessary to understand and apply AI algorithms and models and analyze AI algorithm outputs. It focuses on essential aspects of algebra, probability, and applied statistics.
outcomes: Apply basic algebraic operations and solve linear equations, inequalities, and systems of equations.
Analyze and graph various types of functions, including linear, quadratic, polynomial, rational, exponential, and logarithmic functions.
Perform operations with functions, including composition and finding inverses.
Solve quadratic, higher-degree polynomial, exponential, and logarithmic equations.
Use algebraic models to represent and solve real-world problems, including those involving sequences and series.
Understand and differentiate between descriptive and inferential statistics, including the use of statistical measures and distributions.
Organize and summarize data using tables, charts, and graphs, and interpret measures of central tendency and variability.
Understand and apply fundamental probability principles
topics: Equations and the concept of function: linear, quadratic, higher-degree polynomial, exponential, logarithmic, and rational functions; complex numbers.

name: Computer Science Foundations
description: A deeply technical understanding of the infrastructure and functioning of cyberspace is essential for cyber operators. They must understand the basic building blocks of cyberspace including digital logic, data encoding, and data structures. Additionally, they must be skilled in logical and algorithmic thinking.
outcomes: Design logic circuits that perform basic computational tasks.
Encode and decode data to and from binary format.
Define fundamental data structures and their appropriate uses.
Apply the principles of abstraction and modularity in the design of software.
Characterize the complexity of algorithms.
Identify when heuristics are needed for finding practical solutions to algorithmic problems.

name: AI Governance, Laws, and Ethics
description: This KU covers the governance, legal, and ethical considerations surrounding AI systems, including the frameworks and principles that guide the responsible development and deployment of AI technologies.
outcomes: Analyze AI Governance related to the US and International legal and regulatory frameworks, organizational policies, and oversight mechanisms.
Describe the societal responsibility of AI developers, operators, and users to act legally and ethically at all times.
Describe AI ethical considerations (Fairness(bias)), Transparency, Accountability, and Non-discrimination).
Assess the impact of laws and regulations on AI development and security.
topics: Legal and Regulatory Frameworks (domestic and international)
Standards and standard-setting bodies for AI development and deployment
Internal organizational policies guiding legal and ethical AI use
Oversight and Compliance mechanisms for monitoring and enforcing AI regulations and policies
Stakeholder Engagement (Boards of Directors, Leadership, Customers, Public)
AI Laws and Regulations, including assessment of practical examples/case studies
Data Protection and Privacy - GDPR, CCPA, HIPAA, EU AI Act, organizational retention policies
Develop policies guiding data privacy and protection related to AI
Ethical Considerations (transparency, fairness, accountability, beneficence, privacy, trust/trustworthiness)

name: AI Fundamentals
description: This KU covers the basic concepts of Artificial Intelligence (AI). It includes basic security principles surrounding artificial intelligence and its applications.
outcomes: Describe the principles and concepts of AI, including terminology, components, tools, various AI technologies, and their evolution.
Explain classical artificial intelligence algorithms, such as search and optimization algorithms.
Explore and assess how AI technologies can transform cybersecurity practices, including enhancing security protocols and predicting security risks (e.g., threats and vulnerabilities).
Evaluate the suitability of an AI tool for a specific task, particularly within the context of cybersecurity.
Discuss applications of Artificial Intelligence techniques in cybersecurity and related domains.
Describe the ethical considerations and potential risks associated with AI, focusing on bias, privacy, safety, and security throughout the lifecycle.
Identify solutions to business problems by utilizing intelligent systems and machine learning.
topics: Overview and evolution of the broad field of Artificial Intelligence
Classes of AI tools and techniques (classical AI, expert systems, machine learning, neural networks, generative AI)
Classic AI algorithms (search, optimization, rule-based systems, decision trees)
Safety and security principles of AI

name: Machine Learning Fundamentals
description: This KU covers fundamental concepts of Machine Learning (ML) and their applications in cybersecurity. It includes basic principles, techniques, and tools used in Machine Learning, with an emphasis on their applications to cybersecurity domains.
outcomes: Define machine learning and discuss frequently used machine learning methods.
Describe various machine learning algorithms.
Compare and contrast various ML methods.
Identify the classes of problems for which machine learning is best suited.
Evaluate the performance and effectiveness of different Machine Learning methods and tools.
Identify various data types and formats used by AI systems.
Apply Machine Learning methods effectively for cybersecurity applications.
Analyze security case studies and threats using Machine Learning techniques.
topics: Introduction to ML tools and frameworks
Overview of commonly used ML tools and frameworks
Basic model training, testing, and validation
Introduction to decision trees, support vector machines, and K-nearest neighbors
Basic applications and understanding of how these algorithms function
Introduction to supervised learning: neural networks, decision trees, and regression
Introduction to unsupervised learning: clustering and dimensionality reduction
Overview of semi-supervised and reinforcement learning
Common data formats and standards: CSV, JSON, binary
Basic data pre-processing techniques: deduplication, outlier management, normalization, and feature extraction
Introduction to Neural Networks and Deep Learning
Introduction to deep learning concepts: convolutional and recurrent neural networks, long short-term memory (LSTM)
Overview of parameter tuning, overfitting, and mitigation strategies
Application of ML methods in cybersecurity: anomaly detection, attack detection, network traffic analysis
Case studies in cybersecurity using ML techniques
Basic concepts of generative AI: large language models, prompt engineering, and fine-tuning

name: Basic Networking
description: The intent of the Basic Networking (BNW) Knowledge Unit is to provide students with a basic understanding of how networks are designed, built and operate, and to give students experience with basic network analysis tools. Students are exposed to the concept of potential vulnerabilities in a network.
outcomes: Describe and explain the fundamental concepts, technologies, components and issues related to communications and data networks.
Apply networking concepts to design a basic network architecture given a specific need and set of hosts/clients.
Apply and demonstrate knowledge of networking concepts by tracking and identifying the data packets involved in a simple TCP connection (or perform a trace of such a connection).
Apply and demonstrate use of a network monitoring tool to observe the flow of packets (e.g., WireShark).
Perform and examine results of network mapping (i.e., enumeration and identification of network components) (e.g., Nmap).
Describe common network vulnerabilities.
topics: Network media (e.g., wired, optical, and wireless)
Network Architectures and topologies (e.g., PAN, LAN/WAN, DMZ, Enclaves, VLAN, NAT, subnetting, supernetting, bus, star, partial and full mesh, peer-to-peer, client-server)
Common Network Devices and their role in the network (e.g., Routers, Switches, clients and servers, Wireless Access Points, VPNs, Firewalls (hardware, software, virtual), All-in-One Appliances)
Network Protocols introduction (e.g., IP, TCP, UDP, ICMP)
Network Services and protocols introduction (e.g., DNS, NTP, VLAN, DHCP, etc.)
Network Applications and protocols introduction (e.g., SMTP, HTTP, VoIP, SSH, etc.)
Use of basic network administration tools (e.g., PING, Traceroute, SNMP)
Overview of Network Security Issues (e.g., Zero Trust, Defense-in-depth, SIEM/SOAR, Best Practices)
Log analysis (e.g., traffic, threat prevention, audit, event, session, Geo-location, user activity, system, compliance)
Basic business continuity and disaster recovery (e.g., basics of DRP, BCP, IRP)

name: Network Defense
description: The intent of the Network Defense (NDF) Knowledge Unit is to provide students with knowledge of the concepts used in defending a network and the basic tools and techniques that can be taken to protect a network and communication assets from cyber threats.
outcomes: Describe and discuss the key concepts in network defense (defense in depth, minimizing exposure, etc.).
Explain and discuss how network defense tools (e.g., firewalls, IDS, etc.) are used to defend against attacks and mitigate vulnerabilities.
Analyze and evaluate how security policies are implemented on systems to protect a network.
Evaluate how network operational procedures relate to network security.
topics: Minimizing Exposure (e.g., Attack Surface and Vectors)
Network security policies as they relate to network defense/security

name: Advanced Math for AI
description: This KU covers the deeper mathematical background needed to understand, develop, train, and optimize AI algorithms and models, as well as to secure them during their lifecycle. It includes essential mathematical concepts such as calculus, optimization techniques, and a more in-depth exploration of linear algebra compared to the Math Fundamentals KU.
outcomes: Demonstrate understanding of vectors, matrices, correlation, and regression of data.
Demonstrate the application of partial derivatives (e.g., the chain rule) to AI applications.
Apply mathematical principles to analyze, develop, and evaluate algorithms and models using statistical techniques.
Analyze mathematical problems (e.g., graph, tree search problems, training neural networks, etc.) and determine appropriate techniques for an applied context.
Construct and implement AI algorithms (e.g., linear equations, graphs, tree search problems, etc.) using fundamental mathematical principles.
Demonstrate the use of hypothesis testing
topics: Differential and integral calculus, including partial derivatives, multivariate calculus, optimization techniques, and calculus of variations

name: Machine Learning Algorithms
description: This KU covers fundamental Machine Learning (ML) methods, their principles, and their implementations.
outcomes: Compare and contrast various ML algorithms.
Identify and implement the appropriate algorithm for specific problems based on the data provided.
Determine the optimal learning paradigm(s) for specific use cases.
Implement and assess the performance of various ML algorithms as applied to a specific problem.
Tune algorithm parameters to improve accuracy and robustness.
Implement ensemble algorithms by combining different techniques to solve problems.
topics: Classic AI Algorithms (Knowledge representation, Rule-based systems & Decision trees, Naive Bayes, support vector machines)
Supervised learning: advanced decision trees, random forests, and regression techniques
Unsupervised learning: in-depth clustering methods and dimensionality reduction
Semi-supervised learning: advanced techniques and applications
Reinforcement learning: advanced strategies and implementations
Active learning: practical applications and strategies
Application of neural networks in ensemble methods
Feature engineering: advanced techniques and optimization
Algorithm performance evaluation: precision, recall, F1-score, ROC curves, and AUC
Cross-validation techniques: k-fold, leave-one-out, and their impact on model tuning
Constructing algorithms to improve accuracy and robustness in high-dimensional datasets

name: Deep Learning
description: This KU covers implementing various Deep Learning (DL) methods, algorithms, and architectures using libraries and frameworks.
outcomes: Implement a multilayer artificial neural network.
Model sequential data using recurrent neural networks.
Explain the importance and concepts of activation and loss functions in deep neural networks.
Implement common techniques for generating synthetic data.
Describe the use-case of reinforcement learning for model training.
Validate the performance of a trained neural network.
Evaluate the explainability of a trained neural network using XAI methods.
Identify the best learning paradigm(s) for a specific use case.

name: Model Selection, Evaluation, and Specification
description: This KU covers the specification, selection, and evaluation of AI/ML models, including techniques for choosing appropriate models, evaluating their performance, and specifying model requirements based on various criteria.
outcomes: Identify the requirements of a task to guide model selection.
Apply criteria for model selection based on problem requirements.
Analyze the appropriateness and performance of different AI/ML models for a specific task using various metrics.
Evaluate the impact of different inputs, prompts, and hyperparameter combinations on model performance and implement techniques to optimize ML models.
Evaluate the trade-offs between conflicting goals and requirements in the selection and evaluation of a model.
Evaluate the impact of data quality and bias on model performance.
Evaluate the ethical concerns in data acquisition, model selection, and model implementation.
Justify the choice of evaluation methods based on the model.
topics: AI types of models and capabilities
ML Training (model selection/design, training performance monitoring, benchmarking and performance evaluation, class imbalance/regulation)
ML Model manipulation - Hyperparameter tuning, feature engineering, data augmentation, data reduction
Limitation of assumption of AI tools
Model Resilience (adversarial evaluation/red teaming, performance monitoring, tracking distributional shift, recalibration, versioning)
Accuracy, precision, recall, F1-score, confusion matrix

name: Securing the AI Lifecycle
description: This KU covers securing the AI lifecycle, including the development, deployment, and maintenance of AI systems. It includes best practices and strategies for ensuring the security and integrity of AI models throughout their lifecycle.
outcomes: Assess threats and prioritize risks at different stages of the AI lifecycle.
Describe the security challenges and vulnerabilities at each stage of the AI lifecycle.
Examine and analyze vulnerabilities in connections between AI components.
Apply best practices for maintaining the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of AI-enabled systems.
Design, implement, and evaluate security measures for protecting AI models.
Integrate AI models into systems and implement strategies to mitigate risk from vulnerabilities.
topics: Threat Modeling (understand AI attacker goals and objectives)

Security-related concerns at each phase of the AI development cycle across multiple frameworks, domain models (e.g., Security Lifecycle, Software Development Lifecycle (SDLC), CISSP domains, MITRE ATLAS)
Data acquisition security and data flow security
Understand data attribution and provenance throughout data collection, processing, and sharing
Model development - Identify and mitigate security threats that could affect model integrity
Address static threats (model poisoning) and dynamic threats (adversarial attacks during model development)
AI supply chain sources (e.g., libraries and tools) and associated risks/threats
Machine Learning Operations (MLOPS) (data pipeline, deployment infrastructure engineering — cloud vs on-prem vs edge)
Security of connected AI models, including federated learning systems
Validation and traceability of AI models
Stakeholder engagement and communication about human-model interactions

name: Risk Management of AI
description: This KU covers the principles and practices of security assessment and risk management of AI systems. It includes methodologies for assessing system security, evaluating vulnerabilities, and implementing measures to mitigate identified risks.
outcomes: Evaluate and select appropriate benchmarking frameworks for AI Systems.
Produce comprehensive reports with actionable recommendations for risk mitigation.
Conduct continuous assessment and improvement of AI systems.
Design and develop mitigation strategies for ML and AI threats.
Assess the impact of identified vulnerabilities on AI systems.
Implement strategies to mitigate identified security vulnerabilities.
Map attack surfaces and develop comprehensive threat models.
topics: AI frameworks (e.g., MITRE ATLAS, NIST, OWASP LLM Top 10)
Risk mitigation models and plans, policies, and procedures
Threat modeling, monitoring, and threat detection
Build confidentiality, integrity, and availability into AI from the design stage
Define frameworks and processes incorporating CIA in AI throughout the life-cycle

name: Adversarial Learning
description: This KU covers the principles and techniques of adversarial learning, including generating adversarial attack examples, defenses against adversarial attacks, and the implications for AI security and robustness.
outcomes: Investigate how adversarial examples can be crafted to manipulate machine learning models.
Identify and analyze attacker objectives with respect to AI targets.
Assess the robustness of AI models against adversarial attacks.
Apply defenses to protect AI models from adversarial attacks.
Understand ethical and privacy issues with Adversarial Attacks.
Model psychological aspects of insider threats using AI.
topics: Formulation of attacker objectives (OSINT, MITRE ATLAS matrix)
Adversarial attacks and techniques (data poisoning, evasion attacks)
Adversarial defense techniques (Model protection and privacy, data sanitization, evasion defense)
Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs) for defending against GAN attacks
Measuring AI model robustness against attacks
Evaluating and mapping cyber operations objectives to AI algorithms
Ethical and privacy implications of attacks on AI systems

name: AI for Security Assessments
description: This KU covers the principles and practices of conducting security assessments and evaluations leveraging AI. It includes methodologies for assessing organizations, evaluating vulnerabilities, and implementing measures to mitigate identified risks.
outcomes: Conduct security evaluations using AI enhancements to standard tools and techniques.
Produce comprehensive reports with actionable recommendations.
Leverage AI to assess the impact of identified vulnerabilities and design and implement mitigation strategies.
Perform threat modeling and develop mitigation strategies.
Map attack surfaces and develop comprehensive threat models.
topics: Assessing and conducting monitoring and detection leveraging AI
Threat modeling, monitoring, and threat detection

name: Defensive Applications of AI
description: This KU covers the application of AI in strengthening defensive cybersecurity measures. Students will learn how AI-driven tools and techniques can improve the detection, analysis, and response to cyber threats.
outcomes: Implement AI techniques to enhance security posture and automate cybersecurity processes.
Develop and apply AI and machine learning models to identify cyber risks (e.g., vulnerabilities and threats) and their mitigation.
Understand frameworks like MITRE ATLAS for AI-driven cyber threat intelligence.
Understand Explainable AI-driven cybersecurity solutions.
topics: Internal cybersecurity data sources (e.g., network flows, malware, log files, etc.)
Machine and Deep learning for cybersecurity
Supervised and unsupervised learning models in threat detection
Training and testing ML models with cybersecurity datasets
Cyber Threat Intelligence and Analysis Frameworks
Natural Language Processing (NLP) for Cyber Threat Intelligence
Malware analysis and detection (e.g., Reverse Engineering)
AI-based Network Intrusion Detection Systems (NIDS)/Host Intrusion Detection System (HIDS)
AI-based vulnerability defense and repair mechanisms
AI for blue team operations / Incident Response
Understanding the limitations of AI-driven solutions

name: Offensive Applications of AI
description: This KU covers the application of Artificial Intelligence (AI) in conducting offensive cybersecurity operations. It includes strategies for leveraging AI in penetration testing, exploiting vulnerabilities, and automating cyber attacks.
outcomes: Identify and explain adversarial attacks on machine learning models.
Identify opportunities for AI to enable offensive cybersecurity operations.
Supplement current offensive Tactics, Techniques, and Procedures (TTPs) with AI.
Evaluate the effectiveness of implementing AI for conducting cyber attacks.
Discuss the ethical and legal implications of AI-enabled cyber offensive operations.
Correlate offensive AI techniques to existing cybersecurity frameworks.
topics: External cybersecurity data sources (e.g., OSINT, Dark Web, IoT search engines, cybersecurity data repositories)
Vulnerability discovery (e.g., scanning, code analysis, reverse engineering)
Penetration testing and exploitation (e.g., automated exploit generation, CVE-to-exploit)
Use of AI for attack model frameworks (e.g., cyber kill chain, ATT&CK)
Ethical and legal considerations for AI-enabled cybersecurity operations
White-box vs gray-box vs black-box attacks
Formulation and mapping objectives to AI algorithms and TTPs
